Because you need to remember to invoke super and if you don'=
t, everything
will break.

Imagine a world where whenever you want to overr=
ide a method, you need to
look up its javadoc to know if you need to call s=
uper or not...

> That's just OO.

It's well established as poor OO.  Real =
OO recommends to override methods to
specialize them.  If you want to provi=
de functionality that should always be
"enhanced" by subclasses and never r=
eplaced, you should provide template
methods ("hooks"), as you correctly po=
inted out.

The following code guarantees that Parent.setUp() will always b=
e run, no
matter how Parent is subclassed:

public class Parent {
  private=
 void setUp() {
    onSetUp();  // hook
    // do the thing that should alw=
ays be invoked
  }

  public void onSetUp() {}  // default is to do nothing=

}

public class SubClass extends Parent {
  public void onSetUp() {
    //=
 add my own logic to Parent.setUp()
  }
}

> As I wrote elsewhere, if super=
.xxx() bothers 
> you, refactor to Template Method.

It's not always possib=
le since it depends on whether the base class
implemented the Template Meth=
od pattern or not (JUnit didn't).
